title: The Making of the Atomic Bomb
author: Richard Rhodes

title: The Summer Book
author: Tove Jansson
comment: Charming vignettes of life on an island in the Gulf of Finland during summer. Nostalgic yet (somehow) not overly sentimental.

title: A Primate's Memoir: A Neuroscientist's Unconventional Life Among the Baboons
author: Robert Sapolsky
comment: People mistake this for a popular science book, but it's actually one of the best travel books anyone has written.

title: Working in Public: The Making and Maintenance of Open Source Software
author: Nadia Eghbal
comment: Really good at highlighting how the economic and social incentives around maintaining open source software greatly differ from what most people think.

title: The Americanization of Benjamin Franklin
author: Gordon S. Wood
comment: Psychologically astute biography of Franklin that cuts through all the mythology. I was shocked how interesting and different his story is compared to what I thought I knew.

title: Twilight of the Gods: War in the Western Pacific 1944-1945
author: Ian W. Toll
comment: Helped me appreciate how miraculous it is that the War in the Pacific ended without even greater bloodshed.

title: Piranesi
author: Susanna Clarke
comment: A strange and wonderful puzzle. It reminds me more of games like Myst or The Witness than of any other book.

title: Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell
author: Susanna Clarke
comment: The best work of Romanticism in over a generation.

title: Artificial Intelligence: A Guide for Thinking Humans
author: Melanie Mitchell
comment: A useful reality check on the possibility of general AI in the near future.

title: Strangers Drowning: Grappling with Impossible Idealism, Drastic Choices, and the Overpowering Urge to Help
author: Larissa MacFarquhar
comment: Several critics failed to recognize that this book's refusal to draw moral conclusions about its subjects is a great strength, rather than a failing.

title: Blindsight
author: Peter Watts
comment: The achievement here is aliens that really feel alien.

title: Secondhand Time: The Last of the Soviets
author: Svetlana Alexievich
comment: Interviews with people who can remember what it was like before modernity.

title: Bloodlands: Europe Between Hitler and Stalin
author: Timothy Snyder
comment: Very grim, as you might expect. It can be useful, though, to remember history's great capacity for inhumanity.

title: Inhuman Land
author: JÃ³zef Czapski
comment: Stunning first-person account of a Polish officer's experience of World War II. I envy Czapski's sensitivity to art and poetry.

title: The Master and Margarita
author: Mikhail Bulgakov
comment: Anti-Soviet satire. But the real attraction here is the novel's characterization of Satan.

title: The Right Stuff
author: Tom Wolfe
comment: Didion once said that writers are always selling somebody out. Presumably, she had Tom Wolfe in mind. This is a hatchet job. But god damn if it's not artfully done.

title: The Conquering Tide: War in the Pacific Islands 1942-1944
author: Ian W. Toll
comment: A perfect survey of the war in the Pacific theater. By the way, that part of the war remains grossly underrated as a historical subject.

title: The Conflict Shoreline: Colonialism as Climate Change in the Negev Desert
author: Eyal Weizman and Fazal Sheikh
comment: A forensic history of the Negev desert, but channeling Braudel and James C. Scott. I don't share the authors' political views and it still drew me in.

title: The Invisibility Cloak
author: Ge Fei
comment: Perhaps the perfect novel on modern China. Understated and charming.

title: Being Mortal: Medicine and What Matters in the End
author: Atul Gawande
comment: Changed how I think about aging. So much so that I felt almost physically ill as I read it.

title: The Forest Unseen: A Year's Watch in Nature
author: David George Haskell
comment: Nominally about forest ecology. Really about the limits of human observation and mindfulness. Those limits are further out than most of us realize.

title: Superforecasting: The Art and Science of Prediction
author: Philip Tetlock
comment: I would start here if I ever needed to make serious predictions.

title: Altered Carbon
author: Richard K. Morgan
comment: Possibly the best cyberpunk novel since Neuromancer.

title: The Structure of Scientific Revolutions
author: Thomas Kuhn
comment: So much of the existing thought about our future would benefit from taking Kuhn more seriously.

title: The Last Samurai
author: Helen DeWitt
comment: Ultimately, this one is about how to cope with the world when it fails to live up to our expectations.

title: Suttree
author: Cormac McCarthy
comment: McCarthy channeling a gothic Huck Finn. As close to self-recommending as you can get.

title: The Myth of the Rational Voter: Why Democracies Choose Bad Policies
author: Bryan Caplan
comment: Well argued and persuasive, but perhaps too radical for its own good. In my experience, few people who read this change their behavior, but should that count against the book or against the people?

title: The Magic Mountain
author: Thomas Mann
comment: Mann covers so much ground and has so many ideas that this is like reading twenty novels interwoven together.

title: Leaves of Grass
author: Walt Whitman
comment: A useful remedy for excessive pessimism and cynicism.

title: Awakenings
author: Oliver Sacks
comment: Makes you feel like the world is bigger and more alien than you imagined. We could all use more of that on a day-to-day basis.

title: Pnin
author: Vladimir Nabokov
comment: Nabokov's most underrated novel. Ridiculously charming, while still capable of being quite sad.
